Hi Patrik,
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 I am not nea=
rly as knowledgeable in Nihonto as everyone
else on this messege board but =
I do have an extensive "sales" background. A
couple of things come to mind =
before you buy this piece.
If the Seller is knowledgeable in Nihonto, then =
he would be painfully aware
of how important it is to the Buyer to examine =
the nakago. As mentioned
earlier, this should be a simple process. Taking t=
his one step farther, "if"
the seller is knowledgeable, mabe there is somet=
hing on the nakago that
he/she doesn't want you to see. This would all be r=
elated to the asking
price of course.=A0 If the seller isn't knowledgeable,=
 have you explained to
the seller just how simple it would be to remove the=
 tsuka?
Just seems "odd" to me. Has anyone else out there been denied acces=
s to a
nakago?=A0 I'm curious.
=A0
Mark Jaillet
